message.content: The generated code uses in-memory data structures (Python dictionaries) to store the clubs and users. This means that the data will be lost when the application is restarted. A better approach would be to use a database to persist the data. This could be a simple file-based database like SQLite or a full-fledged database server like PostgreSQL or MySQL. This would allow the data to persist across application restarts and also provide better performance and scalability.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation of the `join_club` function allows any user to join any club, as long as the club is not private. However, the original task specifies that a user should only be able to join a club if they have been invited. Therefore, a possible improvement would be to add an `invitations` attribute to the `User` class, and check this attribute in the `join_club` function to ensure that the user has been invited to the club they are trying to join.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation does not have a way to send invitations to users to join a club. According to the original task, a user should be able to send an invitation to another user to join a club. Therefore, a possible improvement would be to add a new endpoint, such as `/send_invitation`, which would allow a user to send an invitation to another user to join a specific club. This endpoint would update the `invitations` attribute of the invited user.
